 Some time about the third century the leaders of the Church met to decide what was and was not the inspired word of God. They kept some and threw out some of the earlier traditional writings. These books were written in Hebrew, Aramaic, and Greek. In the 4th century St. Jerome translated the Biblia into the common language of the day, Latin. In the 16th Century the Church again affirmed the books that constituted the Bible. Protestant sects reject some of these books based on the mystical significance of the number of books in the Old Testament and whether Christ was ever represented to have quoted one of these books.
 
 The first English Bible was the Douay-Rhiems translation, used by the Catholic Church until the 1960's. The King James Version was finished in 1611 and is still the predominant version used among fundamentalist christians.

Does this help to answer any questions?
 
 
 Ezekiel predicted Babylon would conquer Egypt and was wrong.
 
 Ezekiel predicts that Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon will conquer Egypt utterly destroying it, slaying and scattering it's people, and that it will stay uninhabited for 40 years.
 
 In 568 BCE Nebuchadrezzar tried to conquer Egypt and Egypt survived with no apparent damage.
 
 Aahmes ruled for another generation over a prosperous Egypt and lived to see Nebuchadrezzar die. No Egyptians were scattered or dispersed.
 
 (Ezek 29:10 NRSV) therefore, I am against you, and against your channels, and I will make the land of Egypt an utter waste and desolation, from Migdol to Syene, as far as the border of Ethiopia.
 
 (Ezek 29:11 NRSV) No human foot shall pass through it, and no animal foot shall pass through it; it shall be uninhabited forty years.
 
 (Ezek 29:12 NRSV) I will make the land of Egypt a desolation among desolated countries; and her cities shall be a desolation forty years among cities that are laid waste. I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, and disperse them among the countries.
 
 (Ezek 30:10 NRSV) Thus says the Lord GOD: I will put an end to the hordes of Egypt, by the hand of King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon.
 
 (Ezek 30:11 NRSV) He and his people with him, the most terrible of the nations, shall be brought in to destroy the land; and they shall draw their swords against Egypt, and fill the land with the slain.

 "Thus says the Lord GOD: I will put an end to the hordes of Egypt, by the hand of King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon"
 
 That would mean that not only would Nebuchadrezzar need to rise from the dead to defeat Egypt but also Babylon would have to rise again and Egypt would have to once again become a powerful nation. The real truth is likely to be that the writer of Ezekiel was trying to boost the confidence of the Babylonian army when he put that passage in the Bible. It just didn't have the effect needed to help them defeat Egypt.

 Ezekiel predicted Babylon would conquer Egypt and was wrong.
 
 Ezekiel predicts that Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon will conquer Egypt utterly destroying it, slaying and scattering it's people, and that it will stay uninhabited for 40 years.
 
 In 568 BCE Nebuchadrezzar tried to conquer Egypt and Egypt survived with no apparent damage.
 
 Aahmes ruled for another generation over a prosperous Egypt and lived to see Nebuchadrezzar die. No Egyptians were scattered or dispersed.
 
 (Ezek 29:10 NRSV) therefore, I am against you, and against your channels, and I will make the land of Egypt an utter waste and desolation, from Migdol to Syene, as far as the border of Ethiopia.
 
 (Ezek 29:11 NRSV) No human foot shall pass through it, and no animal foot shall pass through it; it shall be uninhabited forty years.
 
 (Ezek 29:12 NRSV) I will make the land of Egypt a desolation among desolated countries; and her cities shall be a desolation forty years among cities that are laid waste. I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, and disperse them among the countries.
 
 (Ezek 30:10 NRSV) Thus says the Lord GOD: I will put an end to the hordes of Egypt, by the hand of King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon.
 
 (Ezek 30:11 NRSV) He and his people with him, the most terrible of the nations, shall be brought in to destroy the land; and they shall draw their swords against Egypt, and fill the land with the slain.
